body: What testing has been done to validate this approach? cc @junrao

I think this is a good change. A couple of comments:

1. We should add a note to upgrade.html
2. Does this need a KIP since it's a potential breaking change?

Sure.
Idea for testing:
Create a Kafka Streams topology, which contains a `org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.Processor` which has a state store.
In the toplogy use a foreach action (`org.apache.kafka.streams.kstream.KStream#foreach`) which in it's `org.apache.kafka.streams.kstream.ForeachAction#apply` method calls `Thread.sleep(< ms > max.poll.interval.ms >)`

This should result in `StreamsException: stream-thread [StreamThread-1] Failed to rebalance` thrown to the `UncaughtExceptionHandler`. The cause of this exception should be `CommitFailedException: Commit cannot be completed since the group has already rebalanced` instead of `ProcessorStateException: Error opening store <storeName> at location <storePath>` with a nested cause `RocksDBException: IO error: lock <storePath>/LOCK: No locks available`

Streams config for test:
max.poll.interval.ms = \<small value\> - so the test doesn't last long, because default is 300000 (5 minutes).

What do you think of this test strategy?
Did you intend to create this PR? If not, can you please close it?

@ewencp I should think ConnectException would only happen if the remote process stopped listening, but you'd still be spamming users in that case. Let me add a general wrapper with a cooldown for log messages and use it here. Then if we find other spammy things, we can reuse it hopefully.

Hi! Is there any news on when 2.12 binaries will be available for the next patch version? There are a couple of libraries that depend on this. Thanks.

I've opened a separate PR for the version using `ConcurrentLinkedQueue`: #2195. I'll go ahead and close this one. I can definitely appreciate Ismael's reluctance to include it in 0.10.1.1, but I also feel bad about leaving a known deadlock out there, especially since we have a solution that seems to have a low impact on performance. Maybe I can punt the decision to Guozhang since he's managing the release üòù .

Something to consider is that internal topic creation can happen in five paths:
1. By a broker upon GroupCoordinatorRequest.
2. By a broker from MetadataRequest querying the internal topic even if "auto.create.topics.enable" is false.
3. By a user when using AdminUtils.
4. By a user when running kafka-topics (which calls AdminUtils).
5. By a broker through AdminManager (which calls AdminUtils) handling CreateTopicsRequest.

Consequences of this PR:
1. is covered correctly by this PR.
2. now accidentally may have the MetadataResponse return GROUP_COORDINATOR_NOT_AVAILABLE for when a MetadataRequest queries the internal topic. Internal topic creation from MetadataRequest in the past used to always succeed since the replication factor was adjusted.
3. AdminUtils.createTopic behavior remains unchanged (though the current behavior is arguably wrong). AdminUtils does a similar cluster size vs. replication factor comparison but throws an InvalidReplicationFactorException if the manually specified replication factor isn't met. If the replication factor is met, it creates the topic, ignoring the broker's offsets.topic.replication.factor config.
4. Same as 3.
5. Same as 3. CreateTopicsResponse including an internal topic will return INVALID_REPLICATION_FACTOR if the manually specified replication factor isn't met.

So scenario 1 has been fixed, 2 has an unexpected change, and 3-5 remain unchanged but potentially do the wrong thing.

Actually folks, it turns out I was testing with max.poll.records = 1000 by mistake. When testing with max.poll.records = 1, the issue remains and this PR is still needed. Sorry about the confusion.

Hey @enothereska, thanks for the patch. Just to clarify, with this fix, the performance discrepancy goes away totally?

@hachikuji with this fix the perf when we use max.poll.records=1 goes up by 50%. However, the perf when we use max.poll.records=1000 is still higher. Example numbers: 10MB/s (mpr=1)->15MB/s(mpr=1 with this PR)->19MB/s(mpr=1000).
Known failure, we are debating on whether to turn off that test while we sort it out. Unrelated to this PR.

@enothereska Thanks, the difference is puzzling... The description from the JIRA doesn't seem quite right because, in spite of the call to `sendFetches`,  no fetches will be sent for any partition which still has buffered records. Could the performance degradation be caused by the overhead of analyzing which fetches need to be sent? How many partitions are in your test case?

@hachikuji I was thinking the same as you. For `max.poll.records=1`, the amount of work done by the user per `poll` could potentially be really low in comparison to the work to figure out which partitions need a `fetch`.

Having said that, I am not sure if it ever makes sense to have such a low `max.poll.records` after KIP-62. It may be reasonable to say that if processing of each record is very cheap, you need to use a higher `max.poll.records` for best performance.

@ijuma Yeah, good point. If the processing is fast enough that `poll` itself is becoming a bottleneck, then it seems safe to increase `max.poll.records` to reduce the number of calls to `poll`. 

One thing I noticed in `Fetcher.fetchablePartitions` is that we're also doing an expensive call to `remove` from an `ArrayList`. We could probably be a bit more clever. In fact, just using a `HashSet` would probably be a nice improvement. Maybe @enothereska could try that and see if it makes a difference?
If poll should be large, I wouldn't over-optimize this case.
@mjsax @guozhangwang are we ok with temporarily suspending these 2 tests until we sort out the issue?
The topic has 1 partition.
@enothereska  @mjsax Is it only transiently failing or consistently failing? How frequent is the failure
Haha, that mostly rules out overhead from `Fetcher`. The only thing left is the `pollNoWakeup`.
It fails transiently for me locally. Usually not in the first run, but if I put it on a look in intellij it fails in subsequent runs. I've sent @mjsax one possible reason for it.

The IntelliJ loop issue is an IntelliJ problem -- I discovered this, too. It's not a test issue. However, the test reveals in internal Streams problem -- the test itself if fine. It's transient and if I run it in a loop in Intellij it fails in about 1 out of 5 runs. Disabling for now is ok with me.

6th way: By a user directly writing to the topic znode in zookeeper.
Consequences of this PR: Unrelated, as the zk write will not receive any error from kafka.
That being said, I don't think we need to worry about users manually creating the __consumer_offsets topic for now, so really we just need to worry about path 1 and maybe 2.

ping @ewencp

@antonnazaruk @mdemierre Sorry for the late reply. We have several timestamp management improvements that were under discussions recently and `punctuate()` semantics is one of them, and that is partially why it took so long as we want to see the whole design before making any concrete decisions on each of these areas.

The current plan is to change the semantics of `punctuate()` to be purely "time driven", instead of "part time driven, and part data-driven". That is, the punctuate function triggering will no longer be dependent whether there are new data arriving, and hence not on the timestamps of the arrival data either (note that the stream time will only be updated when there are new data coming, so if there is not then the stream time will never advance, hence not triggering `punctuate` at all under the current semantics). Instead it will be triggered only by system wall-clock time. 

As for users, the programming pattern would be:

1. If you need to add a pure time-driven computation logic, use `punctuate()`.
2. If you need to add a data-driven computation logic, you should always use `process()`, and in `process()` users can choose to trigger some specific logic only every some time units, but still when a new data has arrived and hence being processed.

We are about to propose a KIP for this change as it modifies the public APIs and I hope to have it in the next minor release, targeted 2017 Feb.

Merged to trunk. There are still occasional failures for `ResetIntegrationTest`, but that's already happening in trunk.
Filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4479 about removing hardcoded `Time.SYSTEM` in `GroupCoordinator`.

The reason is simple: `toArray` first calls `size` and then iterates through the collection. This is not safe for a collection that is accessed concurrently. Maybe worth checking if there are any other cases like that?

Ah, makes sense.

Indeed there seems to be a similar problem at [Log](https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/core/src/main/scala/kafka/log/Log.scala#L606).

@ijuma I updated the pull request, with the suggested modifications. I forgot to update the documentation but I will do that maybe this weekend or in the beginning of the next one. Also there are couple of files where I don't know how to proceed.
These files are: `GetOffsetshell, ReplicaVerificationTool, SimpleConsumerShell, Consumer Performance, VerifiableLog4jAppender`. One of those are refactored to use `broker-list` instead of `zookeeper`, others are still using the old implementation as far as I can tell because the `metadata.broker.list` property is in use.
